newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Small, mid-sized Brazil firms' output, sales fall.
newsitem.headline: Small, mid-sized Brazil firms' output, sales fall.

text.p: Output, sales and revenue at small and mid-sized Brazilian industrial firms dropped in the first quarter compared with 1996's last three months, the National Industry Confederation (CNI) said.

In a statement, the CNI said a survey revealed "an interruption in the rhythm of recovery of industrial activity compared with 1996's last quarter but a higher level of productivity than last year's first quarter."

The survey, titled "Business Survey of Small and Mid-sized Industry," showed physical production declined in 39 percent of the firms polled and was stable in 37 percent while sales dropped for 42.2 percent of the companies, the CNI said.
"Of 18 states surveyed, only Minas Gerais registered a rise in sales during the period," the statement said.
Revenues fell at 63.8 percent of the companies, due mostly to the drop in sales, it said.
Employment at 50.5 percent of the companies remained steady while 32 percent reduced their work forces and 28.4 percent added employees, it added.
Layoffs were mostly seen at clothing, textile and transport materials firms, the confederation said.
The statement did not say how many firms were polled or give a margin of error for the survey.
Of the firms surveyed, 62.3 percent had no investment in the first quarter.
The best-performing sectors in the period were electrical materials, machine metals, metallurgy and textiles while the worst were publishing, beverages, clothing and footwear.
By states, companies in Minas Gerais, Santa Catarina, Para and Sao Paulo performed the best in the period, it added.
